name: src/index.js
SOCKET_ERROR
description: The error types that cause the {@link SocketEvents} 'error' event to fire.

properties.name: TIMEOUT
properties.description: The ping to the server timed out.

properties.name: NO_ATTEMPTS_LEFT
properties.description: The client ran out of attempts to reconnect to the server.

properties.name: AUTH_INVALID_TOKEN
properties.description: The client is not granted access to the server due to the token being invalid.

properties.name: AUTH_TIMEOUT
properties.description: The client is not granted access to the server because the client took too long to authenticate.

name: DISCONNECT_REASON
description: The disconnect reason that gets passed along with the {@link SocketEvents} 'disconnect' event.

properties.name: SERVER_DISCONNECT
properties.description: The server disconnected the client. A manual reconnect would be required.

properties.name: CLIENT_DISCONNECT
properties.description: The client disconnected from the server. A manual reconnect would be required.

properties.name: PING_TIMEOUT
properties.description: The ping to the server timed-out. The client will automatically try to reconnect.

name: SocketEvents
description:
As ESDoc lacks a way to properly document events, this typedef shows all the different events the client might emit.
The "type" below is the callback argument for the listener.

properties.name: connect
properties.description: Emitted on a successful connect to the server. Called after authentication.

properties.name: disconnect
properties.description: Emitted when the client disconnected from the server. The disconnect reason indicates why.

properties.name: error
properties.description: Emitted when the encounters an error. The first argument is the {@link SOCKET_ERROR} object, indicating what the error object might be.

properties.name: reconnecting
properties.description: Emitted once the clients starts trying to reconnect to the server. Attempt number passed to the listener.

name: MissionControlClient
description:
The mission control client class.

You can easily build your own client implementation, this one is just easy to use and has everything you might need.

The client hides the authentication implementation details from the user, by hijacking the `connect` event.
The connect event only gets called after the authentication scheme is successful.

params.name: url
params.description: The mission control url the client should connect to.

params.name: authToken
params.description: The JWT authentication token that should be used to authenticate.

name: authToken
description: The JWT authentication token that is used to authenticate.

name: socket
description:
The socket.io socket used for the communication.

While it is possible it is recommended not to use this variable directly and to use the exposed {@link MissionControlClient#action} and {@link MissionControlClient#subscribe} methods instead.

name: eventBus
description:
The event bus used to communicate events within the client.

While it is possible it is recommended not to use this variable directly and to use the exposed {@link MissionControlClient#on} and {@link MissionControlClient#subscribe} methods instead.

name: _setupSocketHandlers
description:
This function sets up all the listeners for the socket (connect, disconnect, error, reconnect, etc).

Job of this function is to unify all error events into a shape that makes more sense. See {@link SOCKET_ERROR} for the possible errors.

name: on
description:
Listen to a socket event.

Please note, if you want to subscribe to action or state events, please use the {@link subscribe} method.
The returned function can be used to unsubscribe from the event listener again.
This makes it possible to for example remove inline listeners.

params.name: event
params.description: The socket event you want to listen to.

params.name: listener
params.description: The listener function that will be called on event.

return.description: Returns a function which you can use to remove the event listener.

name: once
description:
Listen to a socket event, and clear it after it's been called once.

Please note, if you want to subscribe to action or state events, please use the {@link subscribe} method.
The returned function can be used to unsubscribe from the event listener again.
This makes it possible to for example remove inline listeners.

params.name: event
params.description: The socket event you want to listen to.

params.name: listener
params.description: The listener function that will be called on event once.

return.description: Returns a function which you can use to remove the event listener.

name: subscribe
description:
Subscribe to a server event (actions, state updates).

To subscribe to a server event, we need to emit a 'subscribe' event to the server so it knows
to broadcast the right events to us. This function automatically handles these 'subscribe' and
'unsubscribe' events so you can simply use this method to do it. When we disconnect from
the server, this function also handles resubscribing to the events.
It returns a function that can you can use to remove the event listener again and unsubscribe from the server.

params.name: serverEvent
params.description: This is the server event you want to subscribe to. Keep in mind these are not general socket events, but rather state / action Mission Control events.

params.name: listener
params.description: The listener function that will be called on event.

return.description: Returns a function which you can use to remove the event listener.

name: action
description:
Execute an action on the mission control server.

This method sends an 'action' event, which the server will use to execute the action and modify
the state accordingly.
examples:
client.action('EXAMPLE:DO', { parameter: 'example' })
client.action('VIDEO-QUEUE:PUSH', { video: { url: '...', format: 'mp4' }})

params.name: action
params.description: The action that you want to execute.

params.name: data
params.description: The data you want to pass to the action function.
